t: Isaiah 1
Rebellion of God’s People
The*p vision of Isaiah the son of Amoz concerning Judah and Jerusalem, which he saw during the reigns of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz and*i Hezekiah, kings of Judah.
Listen,*pn O heavens, and hear, O earth; For*ln the Lord*s speaks, “Sons*ln I have reared and brought up, But*ln they have revolted against Me.
An*ln ox knows its owner, And*ln a donkey its master’s manger, But*iln Israel does not know, My*ln people do not understand.”

Alas,*ln sinful nation, People*ln weighed down with iniquity, Offspring*ln of evildoers, Sons*ln who act corruptly! They*ln have abandoned the Lord,*s They*ln have despised the Holy One of Israel, They*ln have turned away from Him.
Where*ln will you be stricken again, As*iln you continue in your*i rebellion? The*ln whole head is sick And*ln the whole heart is faint.
From*ln the sole of the foot even to the head There*ln is nothing sound in it, Only*iln bruises, welts and raw wounds, Not*ln pressed out or bandaged, Nor*ln softened with oil.
Your*ln land is desolate, Your*ln cities are burned with fire, Your*ln fields—strangers are devouring them in your presence; It*ln is desolation, as overthrown by strangers.
The*ln daughter of Zion is left like a shelter in a vineyard, Like*ln a watchman’s hut in a cucumber field, like a besieged city.
Unless*ln the Lord*s of hosts Had*ln left us a few survivors, We*ln would be like Sodom, We*ln would be like Gomorrah.
God Has Had Enough
Hear*pn the word of the Lord,*s You*ln rulers of Sodom; Give*ln ear to the instruction of our God, You*ln people of Gomorrah.

“What*ln are your multiplied sacrifices to Me?” Says*ln the Lord.*s “I*ln have had enough of burnt offerings of rams And*ln the fat of fed cattle; And*ln I take no pleasure in the blood of bulls, lambs or goats.
When*ln you come to appear before Me, Who*ln requires of you this trampling of My courts?
Bring*ln your worthless offerings no longer, Incense*ln is an abomination to Me. New*ln moon and sabbath, the calling of assemblies— I*ln cannot endure iniquity and the solemn assembly.
I*ln hate your new moon festivals*i and your appointed feasts, They*ln have become a burden to Me; I*ln am weary of bearing them.*i
So*ln when you spread out your hands in*i prayer,*i I*ln will hide My eyes from you; Yes,*ln even though you multiply prayers, I*ln will not listen. Your*ln hands are covered with blood.
“Wash*ln yourselves, make yourselves clean; Remove*ln the evil of your deeds from My sight. Cease*ln to do evil,
Learn*ln to do good; Seek*ln justice, Reprove*ln the ruthless, Defend*ln the orphan, Plead*ln for the widow.
“Let Us Reason”
“Come*pn now, and let us reason together,” Says*ln the Lord,*s “Though*ln your sins are as scarlet, They*ln will be as white as snow; Though*ln they are red like crimson, They*ln will be like wool.
If*ln you consent and obey, You*ln will eat the best of the land;
But*ln if you refuse and rebel, You*ln will be devoured by the sword.” Truly,*ln the mouth of the Lord*s has spoken.
Zion Corrupted, to Be Redeemed
How*pn the faithful city has become a harlot, She*ln who*i was full of justice! Righteousness*ln once lodged in her, But*ln now murderers.
Your*ln silver has become dross, Your*ln drink diluted with water.
Your*ln rulers are rebels And*ln companions of thieves; Everyone*ln loves a bribe And*ln chases after rewards. They*ln do not defend the orphan, Nor*ln does the widow’s plea come before them.
Therefore*ln the Lord God*s of hosts, The*ln Mighty One of Israel, declares, “Ah,*ln I will be relieved of My adversaries And*ln avenge Myself on My foes.
I*ln will also turn My hand against you, And*ln will smelt away your dross as with lye And*ln will remove all your alloy.
Then*ln I will restore your judges as at the first, And*ln your counselors as at the beginning; After*ln that you will be called the city of righteousness, A*ln faithful city.”
Zion*ln will be redeemed with justice And*ln her repentant ones with righteousness.
But*ln transgressors and sinners will be crushed together, And*ln those who forsake the Lord*s will come to an end.
Surely*ln you will be ashamed of the oaks which you have desired, And*ln you will be embarrassed at the gardens which you have chosen.
For*ln you will be like an oak whose leaf fades away Or*ln as a garden that has no water.
The*ln strong man will become tinder, His*ln work also a spark. Thus*ln they shall both burn together And*ln there will be none to quench them.*i
Isaiah 2
God’s Universal Reign
The*p word which Isaiah the son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem.

Now*pn it will come about that In*ln the last days The*ln mountain of the house of the Lord*s Will*ln be established as the chief of the mountains, And*ln will be raised above the hills; And*ln all the nations will stream to it.

And*ln many peoples will come and say, “Come,*ln let us go up to the mountain of the Lord,*s To*ln the house of the God of Jacob; That*ln He may teach us concerning His ways And*ln that we may walk in His paths.” For*ln the law will go forth from Zion And*ln the word of the Lord*s from Jerusalem.

And*ln He will judge between the nations, And*ln will render decisions for many peoples; And*ln they will hammer their swords into plowshares and their spears into pruning hooks. Nation*ln will not lift up sword against nation, And*ln never again will they learn war.
Come,*ln house of Jacob, and let us walk in the light of the Lord.*s

For*ln You have abandoned Your people, the house of Jacob, Because*ln they are filled with*i influences*i from the east, And*ln they*i are*i soothsayers like the Philistines, And*ln they strike bargains*i with the children of foreigners.
Their*ln land has also been filled with silver and gold And*ln there is no end to their treasures; Their*ln land has also been filled with horses And*ln there is no end to their chariots.
Their*ln land has also been filled with idols; They*ln worship the work of their hands, That*ln which their fingers have made.
So*ln the common*i man has been humbled And*ln the man of*i importance*i has been abased, But*ln do not forgive them.
Enter*ln the rock and hide in the dust From*ln the terror of the Lord*s and from the splendor of His majesty.
The*ln proud look of man will be abased And*ln the loftiness of man will be humbled, And*ln the Lord*s alone will be exalted in that day.
A Day of Reckoning Coming
For*pn the Lord*s of hosts will have a day of*i reckoning*i Against*ln everyone who is proud and lofty And*ln against everyone who is lifted up, That*ln he may be abased.
And*ln it*i will*i be*i against all the cedars of Lebanon that are lofty and lifted up, Against*ln all the oaks of Bashan,
Against*ln all the lofty mountains, Against*ln all the hills that are lifted up,
Against*ln every high tower, Against*ln every fortified wall,
Against*ln all the ships of Tarshish And*ln against all the beautiful craft.
The*ln pride of man will be humbled And*ln the loftiness of men will be abased; And*ln the Lord*s alone will be exalted in that day,
But*ln the idols will completely vanish.
Men*iln will go into caves of the rocks And*ln into holes of the ground Before*ln the terror of the Lord*s And*ln the splendor of His majesty, When*ln He arises to make the earth tremble.
In*ln that day men will cast away to the moles and the bats Their*ln idols of silver and their idols of gold, Which*ln they made for themselves to worship,
In*ln order to go into the caverns of the rocks and the clefts of the cliffs Before*ln the terror of the Lord*s and the splendor of His majesty, When*ln He arises to make the earth tremble.
Stop*ln regarding man, whose breath of*i life*i is in his nostrils; For*ln why should he be esteemed?
Isaiah 3
God Will Remove the Leaders
For*pn behold, the Lord God*s of hosts is going to remove from Jerusalem and Judah Both*ln supply and support, the whole supply of bread And*ln the whole supply of water;
The*ln mighty man and the warrior, The*ln judge and the prophet, The*ln diviner and the elder,
The*ln captain of fifty and the honorable man, The*ln counselor and the expert artisan, And*ln the skillful enchanter.
And*ln I will make mere lads their princes, And*ln capricious children will rule over them,
And*ln the people will be oppressed, Each*ln one by another, and each one by his neighbor; The*ln youth will storm against the elder And*ln the inferior against the honorable.
When*ln a man lays hold of his brother in his father’s house, saying,*i “You*ln have a cloak, you shall be our ruler, And*ln these ruins will be under your charge,”
He*ln will protest on that day, saying, “I*ln will not be your*i healer, For*ln in my house there is neither bread nor cloak; You*ln should not appoint me ruler of the people.”
For*ln Jerusalem has stumbled and Judah has fallen, Because*ln their speech and their actions are against the Lord,*s To*ln rebel against His glorious presence.
The*ln expression of their faces bears witness against them, And*ln they display their sin like Sodom; They*ln do not even*i conceal it.*i Woe*ln to them! For*ln they have brought evil on themselves.
Say*ln to the righteous that it*i will*i go*i well with*i them,*i For*ln they will eat the fruit of their actions.
Woe*ln to the wicked! It*i will*i go*i badly with*i him,*i For*ln what he deserves will be done to him.
O*ln My people! Their oppressors are children, And*ln women rule over them. O*ln My people! Those who guide you lead you*i astray And*ln confuse the direction of your paths.
God Will Judge
The*pn Lord*s arises to contend, And*ln stands to judge the people.
The*ln Lord*s enters into judgment with the elders and princes of His people, “It*ln is you who have devoured the vineyard; The*ln plunder of the poor is in your houses.
What*ln do you mean by crushing My people And*ln grinding the face of the poor?” Declares*ln the Lord God*s of hosts.
Judah’s Women Denounced
Moreover,*pn the Lord*s said, “Because the daughters of Zion are proud And*ln walk with heads held high and seductive eyes, And*ln go along with mincing steps And*ln tinkle the bangles on their feet,
Therefore*ln the Lord will afflict the scalp of the daughters of Zion with scabs, And*ln the Lord*s will make their foreheads bare.”
In*p that day the Lord will take away the beauty of their*i anklets, headbands, crescent ornaments,
dangling earrings, bracelets, veils,
headdresses, ankle chains, sashes, perfume boxes, amulets,
finger rings, nose rings,
festal robes, outer tunics, cloaks, money purses,
hand mirrors, undergarments, turbans and veils.

Now*pn it will come about that instead of sweet perfume there will be putrefaction; Instead*ln of a belt, a rope; Instead*ln of well-set hair, a plucked-out scalp; Instead*ln of fine clothes, a donning of sackcloth; And*ln branding instead of beauty.
Your*ln men will fall by the sword And*ln your mighty ones in battle.
And*ln her gates will lament and mourn, And*ln deserted she will sit on the ground.
Isaiah 4
A Remnant Prepared
For*p seven women will take hold of one man in that day, saying, “We will eat our own bread and wear our own clothes, only let us be called by your name; take away our reproach!”
In*p that day the Branch of the Lord*s will be beautiful and glorious, and the fruit of the earth will*i be*i the pride and the adornment of the survivors of Israel.
It will come about that he who is left in Zion and remains in Jerusalem will be called holy—everyone who is recorded for life in Jerusalem.
When the Lord has washed away the filth of the daughters of Zion and purged the bloodshed of Jerusalem from her midst, by the spirit of judgment and the spirit of burning,

then the Lord*s will create over the whole area of Mount Zion and over her assemblies a cloud by day, even smoke, and the brightness of a flaming fire by night; for over all the glory will be a canopy.
There will be a shelter to give*i shade from the heat by day, and refuge and protection from the storm and the rain.
Isaiah 5
Parable of the Vineyard
Let*pn me sing now for my well-beloved A*ln song of my beloved concerning His vineyard. My*ln well-beloved had a vineyard on a fertile hill.

He*ln dug it all around, removed its stones, And*ln planted it with the choicest vine. And*ln He built a tower in the middle of it And*ln also hewed out a wine vat in it; Then*ln He expected it*i to produce good*i grapes, But*ln it produced only*i worthless ones.
“And*ln now, O inhabitants of Jerusalem and men of Judah, Judge*ln between Me and My vineyard.
What*ln more was there to do for My vineyard that I have not done in it? Why,*ln when I expected it*i to produce good*i grapes did it produce worthless ones?
So*ln now let Me tell you what I am going to do to My vineyard: I*ln will remove its hedge and it will be consumed; I*ln will break down its wall and it will become trampled ground.
I*ln will lay it waste; It*ln will not be pruned or hoed, But*ln briars and thorns will come up. I*ln will also charge the clouds to rain no rain on it.”

For*ln the vineyard of the Lord*s of hosts is the house of Israel And*ln the men of Judah His delightful plant. Thus*ln He looked for justice, but behold, bloodshed; For*ln righteousness, but behold, a cry of distress.
Woes for the Wicked
Woe*pn to those who add house to house and*i join field to field, Until*ln there is no more room, So*ln that you have to live alone in the midst of the land!
In*ln my ears the Lord*s of hosts has*i sworn,*i “Surely, many houses shall become desolate, Even*iln great and fine ones, without occupants.
For*ln ten acres of vineyard will yield only*i one bath of*i wine,*i And*ln a homer of seed will yield but*i an ephah of grain.”
Woe*ln to those who rise early in the morning that they may pursue strong drink, Who*ln stay up late in the evening that wine may inflame them!
Their*ln banquets are accompanied*i by lyre and harp, by tambourine and flute, and by wine; But*ln they do not pay attention to the deeds of the Lord,*s Nor*ln do they consider the work of His hands.
Therefore*ln My people go into exile for their lack of knowledge; And*ln their honorable men are famished, And*ln their multitude is parched with thirst.
Therefore*ln Sheol has enlarged its throat and opened its mouth without measure; And*ln Jerusalem’s splendor, her multitude, her din of*i revelry*i and the jubilant within her, descend into*i it.*i
So*ln the common*i man will be humbled and the man of importance*i abased, The*ln eyes of the proud also will be abased.
But*ln the Lord*s of hosts will be exalted in judgment, And*ln the holy God will show Himself holy in righteousness.
Then*ln the lambs will graze as in their pasture, And*ln strangers will eat in the waste places of the wealthy.
Woe*ln to those who drag iniquity with the cords of falsehood, And*ln sin as if with cart ropes;
Who*ln say, “Let Him make speed, let Him hasten His work, that we may see it;*i And*ln let the purpose of the Holy One of Israel draw near And*ln come to pass, that we may know it!”*i
Woe*ln to those who call evil good, and good evil; Who*ln substitute darkness for light and light for darkness; Who*ln substitute bitter for sweet and sweet for bitter!
Woe*ln to those who are wise in their own eyes And*ln clever in their own sight!
Woe*ln to those who are heroes in drinking wine And*ln valiant men in mixing strong drink,
Who*ln justify the wicked for a bribe, And*ln take away the rights of the ones who are in the right!

Therefore,*ln as a tongue of fire consumes stubble And*ln dry grass collapses into the flame, So*ln their root will become like rot and their blossom blow away as dust; For*ln they have rejected the law of the Lord*s of hosts And*ln despised the word of the Holy One of Israel.

On*ln this account the anger of the Lord*s has burned against His people, And*ln He has stretched out His hand against them and struck them down. And*ln the mountains quaked, and their corpses lay like refuse in the middle of the streets. For*ln all this His anger is not spent, But*ln His hand is still stretched out.
He*ln will also lift up a standard to the distant nation, And*ln will whistle for it from the ends of the earth; And*ln behold, it will come with speed swiftly.
No*ln one in it is weary or stumbles, None*ln slumbers or sleeps; Nor*ln is the belt at its waist undone, Nor*ln its sandal strap broken.
Its*ln arrows are sharp and all its bows are bent; The*ln hoofs of its horses seem like flint and its chariot*i wheels like a whirlwind.
Its*ln roaring is like a lioness, and it roars like young lions; It*ln growls as it seizes the prey And*ln carries it*i off with no one to deliver it.*i
And*ln it will growl over it in that day like the roaring of the sea. If*ln one looks to the land, behold, there is darkness and*i distress; Even*ln the light is darkened by its clouds.
Isaiah 6
Isaiah’s Vision
In*p the year of King Uzziah’s death I saw the Lord sitting on a throne, lofty and exalted, with the train of His robe filling the temple.
Seraphim stood above Him, each having six wings: with two he covered his face, and with two he covered his feet, and with two he flew.
And one called out to another and said, “Holy,*pn Holy, Holy, is the Lord*s of hosts, The*ln whole earth is full of His glory.”
And*p the foundations of the thresholds trembled at the voice of him who called out, while the temple was filling with smoke.
Then I said, “Woe*pn is me, for I am ruined! Because*ln I am a man of unclean lips, And*ln I live among a people of unclean lips; For*ln my eyes have seen the King, the Lord*s of hosts.”
Then*p one of the seraphim flew to me with a burning coal in his hand, which he had taken from the altar with tongs.
He touched my mouth with*i it*i and said, “Behold, this has touched your lips; and your iniquity is taken away and your sin is forgiven.”
Isaiah’s Commission
Then*p I heard the voice of the Lord, saying, “Whom shall I send, and who will go for Us?” Then I said, “Here am I. Send me!”
He said, “Go, and tell this people: ‘Keep*pn on listening, but do not perceive; Keep*ln on looking, but do not understand.’

Render*ln the hearts of this people insensitive, Their*ln ears dull, And*ln their eyes dim, Otherwise*ln they might see with their eyes, Hear*ln with their ears, Understand*ln with their hearts, And*ln return and be healed.”
Then*p I said, “Lord, how long?” And He answered, “Until*pn cities are devastated and*i without inhabitant, Houses*ln are without people And*ln the land is utterly desolate,
The*ln Lord*s has removed men far away, And*ln the forsaken places are many in the midst of the land.
Yet*ln there will be a tenth portion in it, And*ln it will again be subject*i to burning, Like*ln a terebinth or an oak Whose*ln stump remains when it is felled. The*ln holy seed is its stump.”
Isaiah 7
War against Jerusalem

Now*p it came about in the days of Ahaz, the son of Jotham, the son of Uzziah, king of Judah, that Rezin the king of Aram and Pekah the son of Remaliah, king of Israel, went up to Jerusalem to wage*i war against it, but could not conquer it.
When it was reported to the house of David, saying, “The Arameans have camped in Ephraim,” his heart and the hearts of his people shook as the trees of the forest shake with the wind.
Then*p the Lord*s said to Isaiah, “Go out now to meet Ahaz, you and your son Shear-jashub, at the end of the conduit of the upper pool, on the highway to the fuller’s field,

and say to him, ‘Take care and be calm, have no fear and do not be fainthearted because of these two stubs of smoldering firebrands, on account of the fierce anger of Rezin and Aram and the son of Remaliah.
Because Aram, with*i Ephraim and the son of Remaliah, has planned evil against you, saying,
“Let us go up against Judah and terrorize it, and make for ourselves a breach in its walls and set up the son of Tabeel as king in the midst of it,”
thus says the Lord God:*s “It shall not stand nor shall it come to pass.
For the head of Aram is Damascus and the head of Damascus is Rezin (now within another 65 years Ephraim will be shattered, so*i that*i it*i is*i no longer a people),
and the head of Ephraim is Samaria and the head of Samaria is the son of Remaliah. If you will not believe, you surely shall not last.” ’ ”
The Child Immanuel
Then*p the Lord*s spoke again to Ahaz, saying,
“Ask a sign for yourself from the Lord*s your God; make it*i deep as Sheol or high as heaven.”
But Ahaz said, “I will not ask, nor will I test the Lord!”*s
Then he said, “Listen now, O house of David! Is it too slight a thing for you to try the patience of men, that you will try the patience of my God as well?
Therefore the Lord Himself will give you a sign: Behold, a virgin will be with child and bear a son, and she will call His name Immanuel.
He will eat curds and honey at the time He knows enough*i to refuse evil and choose good.
For before the boy will know enough*i to refuse evil and choose good, the land whose two kings you dread will be forsaken.
Trials to Come for Judah
The*p Lord*s will bring on you, on your people, and on your father’s house such days as have never come since the day that Ephraim separated from Judah, the king of Assyria.”
In*p that day the Lord*s will whistle for the fly that is in the remotest part of the rivers of Egypt and for the bee that is in the land of Assyria.
They will all come and settle on the steep ravines, on the ledges of the cliffs, on all the thorn bushes and on all the watering places.
In*p that day the Lord will shave with a razor, hired from regions beyond the Euphrates (that*i is,*i with the king of Assyria), the head and the hair of the legs; and it will also remove the beard.
Now*p in that day a man may keep alive a heifer and a pair of sheep;
and because of the abundance of the milk produced he will eat curds, for everyone that is left within the land will eat curds and honey.
And*p it will come about in that day, that every place where there used to be a thousand vines, valued*i at a thousand shekels*i of silver, will become briars and thorns.
People*i will come there with bows and arrows because all the land will be briars and thorns.
As for all the hills which used to be cultivated with the hoe, you will not go there for fear of briars and thorns; but they will become a place for pasturing oxen and for sheep to trample.
Isaiah 8
Damascus and Samaria Fall
Then*p the Lord*s said to me, “Take for yourself a large tablet and write on it in ordinary letters: Swift is the booty, speedy is the prey.
And I will take to Myself faithful witnesses for testimony, Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah.”
So I approached the prophetess, and she conceived and gave birth to a son. Then the Lord*s said to me, “Name him Maher-shalal-hash-baz;
for before the boy knows how to cry out ‘My father’ or ‘My mother,’ the wealth of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria will be carried away before the king of Assyria.”
Again*p the Lord*s spoke to me further, saying,
“Inasmuch*pn as these people have rejected the gently flowing waters of Shiloah And*ln rejoice in Rezin and the son of Remaliah;

Now*ln therefore, behold, the Lord is about to bring on them the strong and abundant waters of the Euphrates, Even*iln the king of Assyria and all his glory; And*ln it will rise up over all its channels and go over all its banks.
Then*ln it will sweep on into Judah, it will overflow and pass through, It*ln will reach even to the neck; And*ln the spread of its wings will fill the breadth of your land, O Immanuel.
A Believing Remnant
“Be*pn broken, O peoples, and be shattered; And*ln give ear, all remote places of the earth. Gird*ln yourselves, yet be shattered; Gird*ln yourselves, yet be shattered.
Devise*ln a plan, but it will be thwarted; State*ln a proposal, but it will not stand, For*ln God is with us.”
For*p thus the Lord*s spoke to me with mighty power and instructed me not to walk in the way of this people, saying,
“You*pn are not to say, ‘It*i is*i a conspiracy!’ In*ln regard to all that this people call a conspiracy, And*ln you are not to fear what they fear or be in dread of it.*i
It*ln is the Lord*s of hosts whom you should regard as holy. And*ln He shall be your fear, And*ln He shall be your dread.
Then*ln He shall become a sanctuary; But*ln to both the houses of Israel, a stone to strike and a rock to stumble over, And*iln a snare and a trap for the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
Many*ln will stumble over them, Then*ln they will fall and be broken; They*ln will even be snared and caught.”
Bind*p up the testimony, seal the law among my disciples.
And I will wait for the Lord*s who is hiding His face from the house of Jacob; I will even look eagerly for Him.
Behold, I and the children whom the Lord*s has given me are for signs and wonders in Israel from the Lord*s of hosts, who dwells on Mount Zion.
When*p they say to you, “Consult the mediums and the spiritists who whisper and mutter,” should not a people consult their God? Should*i they*i consult*i the dead on behalf of the living?
To the law and to the testimony! If they do not speak according to this word, it is because they have no dawn.
They will pass through the land hard-pressed and famished, and it will turn out that when they are hungry, they will be enraged and curse their king and their God as they face upward.
Then they will look to the earth, and behold, distress and darkness, the gloom of anguish; and they*i will*i be*i driven away into darkness.
Isaiah 9
Birth and Reign of the Prince of Peace

But*p there will be no more*i gloom for her who was in anguish; in earlier times He treated the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali with contempt, but later on He shall make it*i glorious, by the way of the sea, on the other side of Jordan, Galilee of the Gentiles.
The*pn people who walk in darkness Will*ln see a great light; Those*ln who live in a dark land, The*ln light will shine on them.
You*ln shall multiply the nation, You*ln shall increase their gladness; They*ln will be glad in Your presence As*ln with the gladness of harvest, As*ln men rejoice when they divide the spoil.
For*ln You shall break the yoke of their burden and the staff on their shoulders, The*ln rod of their oppressor, as at the battle of Midian.
For*ln every boot of the booted warrior in the battle*i tumult, And*ln cloak rolled in blood, will be for burning, fuel for the fire.

For*ln a child will be born to us, a son will be given to us; And*ln the government will rest on His shoulders; And*ln His name will be called Wonderful Counselor, Mighty God, Eternal*ln Father, Prince of Peace.

There*ln will be no end to the increase of His*i government or of peace, On*ln the throne of David and over his kingdom, To*ln establish it and to uphold it with justice and righteousness From*ln then on and forevermore. The*ln zeal of the Lord*s of hosts will accomplish this.
God’s Anger with Israel’s Arrogance
The*pn Lord sends a message against Jacob, And*ln it falls on Israel.
And*ln all the people know it,*i That*iln is,*i Ephraim and the inhabitants of Samaria, Asserting*ln in pride and in arrogance of heart:
“The*ln bricks have fallen down, But*ln we will rebuild with smooth stones; The*ln sycamores have been cut down, But*ln we will replace them*i with cedars.”
Therefore*ln the Lord*s raises against them adversaries from Rezin And*ln spurs their enemies on,

The*ln Arameans on the east and the Philistines on the west; And*ln they devour Israel with gaping jaws. In*ln spite*i of*i all this, His anger does not turn away And*ln His hand is still stretched out.
Yet*ln the people do not turn back to Him who struck them, Nor*ln do they seek the Lord*s of hosts.
So*ln the Lord*s cuts off head and tail from Israel, Both*iln palm branch and bulrush in a single day.
The*ln head is the elder and honorable man, And*ln the prophet who teaches falsehood is the tail.
For*ln those who guide this people are leading them*i astray; And*ln those who are guided by them are brought to confusion.

Therefore*ln the Lord does not take pleasure in their young men, Nor*ln does He have pity on their orphans or their widows; For*ln every one of them is godless and an evildoer, And*ln every mouth is speaking foolishness. In*ln spite*i of*i all this, His anger does not turn away And*ln His hand is still stretched out.
For*ln wickedness burns like a fire; It*ln consumes briars and thorns; It*ln even sets the thickets of the forest aflame And*ln they roll upward in a column of smoke.
